messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Mei with Kao
messages.msgSnippet: I ve seen kao on a first gen. Sendai Kunikane and on some early Hizen pieces, but in general, kao are a rather Shin-Shinto thing. Gordon ... From: Richard
messages.messageBody:
I've seen kao on a first gen. Sendai Kunikane and on some early Hizen
pieces, but in general, kao are a rather Shin-Shinto thing.

Gordon
----------
From: "Richard Turner" <ikkanshi@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Subject: [nihontostudy] Mei with Kao
Date: Mon, 28 Apr 2003 19:55:55 +0800


Hi all, I was flicking through 4 Aito ( I think this is the title )
Magazines/Catalogues I recieved today and am looking at a very long
inscription that consists of 11 charactures and a Kao. I am working on the
inscription ( should keep me busy for day's ) but am wondeing, when did Kao
come into use on Sword mei ?, was this a Shinto or Shinshinto thing ? or did
it happen in the earlier periods ?.

This sword is dated ???? ???? the 4th year of Bunsei ( 1821 ) I will have
to work on the front section, I assume it is a month or something. The mei
will take a lot longer :-)

cheers all

Rich

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Mei with Kao
messages.msgSnippet: Just an update and correction. I worked out the mei, it wasn t as hard as I initially thought. It reads Shôji Chikuzen No Daijô Taikai Fuji Naotane with Kao.
messages.messageBody:
Just an update and correction. I worked out the mei, it wasn't as hard as I initially thought. It reads Shôji Chikuzen No Daijô Taikai Fuji Naotane with Kao. The Nengo reads Bunsei Gonen Chûshun, Mid spring of 1822 ( I had 1823 originally, sorry )

So, with that out of the way, my original question stands. When were KAO introduced into Mei ?. My original question ws related to swords but it would be interesting to know about kodogu as well.

cheers

Rich T

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
